body:
## Steps to reproduce

Put in your PS profile

``` powershell
Write-Host 'PROFILE'
```

Create a script `./foo.ps1` and `chmod +x` on it

``` powershell
#!/usr/local/bin/powershell
Write-Host 'foo'
```

From bash call `./foo.ps1`
## Expected behavior

Should not load profile

```
ash-3.2$ ./foo.ps1
foo
```

Reason: that's how bash handles it
## Actual behavior

Load profile

```
ash-3.2$ ./foo.ps1
PROFILE
foo
```
## Environment data

v0.4.0

body:
This is part of the overall problem in #939. Our previous CoreConsoleHost avoided a myriad of problems that occur when a `RawUserInterface` class is created and used but no TTY exists (which causes most `System.Console` methods to throw, and these exceptions can be silenced in formatters).

This is not a blocker to merge the console hosts, but it does introduce regressions (see disabled tests in said PR). Most likely the correct way to solve this is to eliminate the dependency on the `RawUI` class when no TTY exists (and thus PowerShell is by necessity running non-interactively).

This blocks some scenarios from working when not in a TTY (say, automated scripts).

body:
Similar to #943, we need a test scenario where the cmdlet requires not only PowerShell, but also additional library dependencies that it deploys in the module folder.

We expected this to work as Windows PowerShell (I believe) supports such a setup; however, it is not working with PowerShell from repo..

From Atanas Atanasov (VMWare partner)

> Now the module loads but the required assemblies (listed in the manifest .psd1 file) need to be in the PowerShell installation folder to be discovered. I’ll workaround it for now by placing my assemblies in the installation folder.

Apparently the module system is failing to load libraries specified in the manifest. The C# library loading logic in Core PowerShell is _very_ different from WIdnows PowerShell, and moreover, PowerShell Core from GitHub repo is different from Core (due to #839). 

/cc @SteveL-MSFT @daxian-dbw

body: Resolves build failure when building for windows - the expected location of dotnet.exe is incorrect. Manually verified by building -FullClr, -runtime ubuntu.14.04-x64 and -runtime win7-x64 Start-PSBuild was expecting dotnet.exe to be located at $env:LocalAppData\Microsoft\dotnet\cli. However, my tests indicate it is located in the parent directory; $env:LocalAppData\Microsoft\dotnet and cli does not exist. Confirmed by manually removing dotnet cli then running the Invoke-WebRequest/Install.ps1 steps manually. DSC doesn't see this error because we build PowerShell through our DSC build script with sets up the environment and avoids the issue. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/971)

body: Use .NET's Environment.MachineName to get host name. I removed both Window's and Linux's native implementation, and updated the XUnit test. I did not remove the GetComputerName from libpsl-native, or its native tests. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/949)
title: remove dependency on native GetHostname

body: This request fixes two items: 1. Certain keybindings don't show up properly when one executes "Get-PSReadlineKeyHandler". This is because some of the ConsoleKeyInfo.KeyChar fields were defined with non-viewable characters. With the recent change to the comparison of ConsoleKeyInfo, to not compare the KeyChar field, we can now modify the Key table to have actualy-viewable characters for KeyChar field. 2. Some of the tab-related commands sometimes show duplicates as tab-completion choices. In my testing, I've only seen this with PSReadLine cmdlets, e.g. two choices of Get-PSReadlineKeyHandler. Duplicates happen because PSReadLine cmdlets show up pre-pended with the Module name also. For example, Get-PSReadlineKeyHandler also show up as PSReadLine\Get-PSReadlineKeyHandler. To eliminate the duplicate, I investigated several options. Since it looks like the CommandCompletion class does generate duplicates intentionally, I've decided to go the filter route and remove the duplicates myself. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/948)
title: Fix display of certain keybindings, and duplicates with tab-completions

body: This resolves #945. Please note that I ran the type catalog generator, but there were no changes. Also this silences some `dotnet restore` warnings. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/947)

title: Update .NET Core packages

body:
Many things have been added .NET Core that may deprecate our own native code in the `libpsl-native` library. We should examine what functionality we use, and what can be deprecated.

For instance: `MachineName` is now [available](https://dotnet.github.io/api/System.Environment.html#System_Environment_MachineName), which could possibly replace [`GetComputerName`](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/src/libpsl-native/src/getcomputername.cpp).

Ideally the entirety of our native library could disappear eventually, but for now we can at least shrink it.

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

title: Reconcile libpsl-native with .NET Core

body:
## Steps to reproduce

On OS X, build PowerShell, then:

``` powershell
> Import-Module PSReadline
```
## Expected behavior

Import successfully.
## Actual behavior

``` powershell
Import-Module : Could not load type 'System.ConsoleColor' from assembly 'mscorlib, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, 
PublicKeyToken=7cec85d7bea7798e'.
At line:1 char:1
+ Import-Module PSReadline
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (:) [Import-Module], TypeLoadException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : System.TypeLoadException,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ImportModuleCommand
```
## Environment data

Please fill in the results of the following commands:

``` sh
$ dotnet --info
.NET Command Line Tools (1.0.0-rc2-002543)

Product Information:
 Version:     1.0.0-rc2-002543
 Commit Sha:  38d0c28a1e

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Mac OS X
 OS Version:  10.11
 OS Platform: Darwin
 RID:         osx.10.11-x64

$ git rev-parse HEAD && git status
1eb205713ef3c9b6b3bdb041549614b4e7721561
On branch andschwa/cmdlet-example
Your branch is up-to-date with 'origin/andschwa/cmdlet-example'.
Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)

    modified:   ../../.vscode/launch.json
    modified:   ../../src/windows-build (new commits)

Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)

    ../../src/Microsoft.PowerShell.ConsoleHost/libgtest.a
    ../../src/Microsoft.PowerShell.ConsoleHost/libgtest_main.a
    ../../src/Microsoft.PowerShell.ConsoleHost/libpsl-native.dylib

no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")

```
## Thoughts

I suspect that this is due to `CorePsTypeCatalog.cs` being generated on Linux, and the .NET Core packages on OS X being slightly different. I'll try updating our packages first. If that doesn't work, then perhaps we need two copies of the type catalog (which would meaning generating another set on OS X).

body:
## Note from @andschwa (hijacking for visibility):

As this is the oldest issue, I'm going to keep it and close all others. `New-PSSession` (whether its loopback on the local machine or not) is PSRP (as is `Enter-PSSession` and `Invoke-Command` etc.), which **is in progress** but **not yet supported**. Please follow the progress on the [PSRP on Linux repo](https://github.com/PowerShell/psl-omi-provider). We (mostly @paulcallen and @palladia) are working hard to get this ready, and clearly hear how much you all want it! Please be patient while we finish the implementation.
### Original issue:

body: This resolves #495 and #912. ~~This is a _work-in-progress_, **do not merge**.~~ Next steps: - [x] ~~fully deprecate `powershell-native` custom host~~ - [x] ensure FullCLR build can still work - [x] remove deprecated `CoreConsoleHost` project - [x] ~~deprecate or reimplement `consoleHostFile` feature~~ - [x] ~~fix~~ mark failing tests as pending - [x] ~~deploy modules in build script rather than as content~~ ~~use `files` like in [libuv](https://github.com/aspnet/libuv-package/blob/dev/src/Libuv/project.json#L15)~~ use shim project - [x] ~~merge our managed ReadLine backup~~ use `System.Console.ReadLine()` - [x] accept --flags - [x] fix stdin/stdout/stderr stream writers - [x] fix non-interactive use of `BufferSize` - [x] fix Linux CI - [x] fix OS X CI (~31 marked as pending until further notice) - [x] fix Windows CI - [x] fix output when there is no TTY (mostly) How it was done: The managed `RawUserInterface` from `CoreConsoleHost` was used to replace the Windows-centric `ConsoleControl` of the `ConsoleHost`. The work done to port `PSReadLine` to Linux enabled a much easier replacement of the `ReadLine` aspects of `ConsoleHostUserInterface`. While this deprecates our previous `ReadLine` implementation; it was required to push .NET Core to implement the APIs necessary to port `PSReadLine`. The managed entrance `Start` function is replaced with a `Main` function for the `dotnet` native host to build an app. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/939)

body:
For Linux, we should support the well-known [XDG Base Directory Specification](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/basedir-spec/basedir-spec-latest.html). Microsoft's other cross-platform applications already do so (such as NuGet).

This should be done sooner than later, because this kind of change post-release is not fun (and requires making it backwards compatible with the original design).

Right now, we stick the user profile and modules under `~/.powershell`, which was a totally arbitrarily chosen location. This should instead be `~/.config/powershell`, and respect the value of `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME`.

One could argue that perhaps modules belong in `$XDG_DATA_HOME` (or `~/.local/share/powershell`) along with the PSReadLine history file.

Now, the XDGBDS is not specifically aimed at OS X. We can do two things: follow the same layout (easier to do, NuGet does this, a lot of people expect it), or tweak the locations to use Apple's special `Library` directories (this is more complex and not as nice).

labels.description: (LEGACY) Helps filter issues that might be higher priority because they directly affect usability
labels.name: Usability

body:
enum and class key run in script will throw error
for example:

```
enum testenum{a;b;c}
```

or

```
class A{
[string]$name
A([string]$name){$this.name=$name}
}
$a=[A]::new("test")
$a.name
```

run this in script, it will throw below error:

> The given assembly name or codebase was invalid. (Exception from HRESULT: 0x80131047)
>   at < ScriptBlock >

body:
We need to create NuGet packages for the next version of PowerShell, and then host them on a private feed (either NuGet enterprise or AppVeyor).

Creating the packages can be done with either NuGet beta on Windows with a custom nuspec and bits copied from each platform, or with `dotnet pack`.

Using `dotnet pack` would be a lot nicer so we could create these packages automatically on any platform; but is blocked by both dotnet/cli#2175 and dotnet/cli#2170.

body:
Per #833 and #917, we now have PSReadLine available as a default module, with most of its functionality. However, this means that as soon as a PSReadLine function is used, PSReadLine becomes the key handler, and we need to ensure a good user experience by fixing these issues:

``` powershell
> Set-PSReadlineOption -EditMode Emacs
```
- [x] backspace is not handled, instead prints `^?`
- [ ] should we set the default edit mode to Emacs instead of Windows?
- [x] ~~Ctrl-D kills window (as an exit signal) when there is nothing to delete (it probably shouldn't)~~

body:
This breaks `Get-Item somSymbolicLinkToDirectory | Get-ChildItem`.
## Steps to reproduce

``` powershell
> mkdir folder
> touch folder/junk
> touch folder/junk2
> ln -s folder link
> $info = Get-Item /absolute/path/to/link # or just `link`
```

This did not repro on Full PowerShell nor on PowerShell Core on Windows; only on Linux.
## Expected behavior

``` powershell
> $info.Target
/absolute/path/to/folder

> $info | Get-ChildItem

Mode                LastWriteTime         Length Name
----                -------------         ------ ----
------          4/27/16   1:45 PM              0 junk
------          4/27/16   2:24 PM              0 junk2
```
## Actual behavior

``` powershell
> $info.Target
./folder

> $info.EnumerateFiles()

Mode                LastWriteTime         Length Name
----                -------------         ------ ----
------          4/27/16   1:45 PM              0 junk
------          4/27/16   2:24 PM              0 junk2

> $info | Get-ChildItem


    Directory: /home/andrew/scratch


Mode                LastWriteTime         Length Name
----                -------------         ------ ----
d----l          4/27/16   2:24 PM                link
```
## Environment data

Please fill in the results of the following commands:

``` sh
$ dotnet --info
.NET Command Line Tools (1.0.0-rc2-002478)

Product Information:
 Version:     1.0.0-rc2-002478
 Commit Sha:  80df3688b1

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     ubuntu
 OS Version:  14.04
 OS Platform: Linux
 RID:         ubuntu.14.04-x64

$ git rev-parse HEAD && git status
1056d63fa871c6fb208490021d548faec3fb5659
On branch removeitem
Your branch is up-to-date with 'origin/removeitem'.
Changes to be committed:
  (use "git reset HEAD <file>..." to unstage)

        modified:   New-Item.Tests.ps1

Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)

        modified:   New-Item.Tests.ps1
```

body: Resolves #914. The [`PSReadLine/PSReadLine`](https://github.com/lzybkr/PSReadLine/tree/master/PSReadLine) subtree was imported to `src/PSReadLine`, and then @palladia's changes to the private fork of PSReadLine were applied on top. I added the `project.json` file necessary to build PSReadLine on Linux, as well as the (slightly modified) module files. PSReadLine is now built with PowerShell and imported by default (though the keybindings are not set, so it's not used until enabled). I also had to disable more snap-in code, thanks @lzybkr for the help. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/917)

body:
## Steps to reproduce

``` powershell
~ |-/ & (Get-PSOutput) # note I did not use --noninteractive, and have also tried just `powershell`
~ |-/ Get-ChildItem foo


    Directory: /home/andrew/foo


Mode                LastWriteTime         Length Name
----                -------------         ------ ----
d-----          4/21/16  12:07 PM                bar

~ |-/ Remove-Item foo
Remove-Item : Cannot prompt user when invoked with --noninteractive option.
At line:1 char:1
+ Remove-Item foo
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidOperation: (:) [Remove-Item], PSInvalidOperationException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : InvalidOperation,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.RemoveItemCommand
```
## Expected behavior

``` powershell
~ |-/ Remove-Item foo
Confirm
The item at /home/andrew/foo has children and the Recurse parameter was not specified. If you continue, all children will be removed with the item. Are you sure you want to continue?

|Y> Yes |A> Yes to All |N> No |L> No to All |S> Suspend [Default is (Y]
```
## Actual behavior

``` powershell
~ |-/ Remove-Item foo
Remove-Item : Cannot prompt user when invoked with --noninteractive option.
At line:1 char:1
+ Remove-Item foo
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidOperation: (:) [Remove-Item], PSInvalidOperationException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : InvalidOperation,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.RemoveItemCommand
```
## Environment data

Please fill in the results of the following commands:

``` sh
$ dotnet --info
~/src/PowerShell master= |-/ dotnet --info
.NET Command Line Tools (1.0.0-rc2-002478)

Product Information:
 Version:     1.0.0-rc2-002478
 Commit Sha:  80df3688b1

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     ubuntu
 OS Version:  14.04
 OS Platform: Linux
 RID:         ubuntu.14.04-x64

$ git status
~/src/PowerShell master= |-/ git status
On branch master
Your branch is up-to-date with 'origin/master'.
nothing to commit, working directory clean
```

body:
This resolves #817.

A PowerShell instance is created to load and execute profile code.
However, if the profile has a parse error, the instance never gets
created, thus we have to check that it's not null before disposing it.
title: Fix bug when loading bad profiles

body:
The dotnet-core and aspnetcidev feeds provide all our required packages.
The aspnetvnext causes `dotnet restore` to take an inordinate amount of
time, which terminates our CI builds.

Reducing the number of feeds brings restore time from scratch down to 3
seconds on my machine.

The aspnetvnext feed was originally added for the CoreCLR xUnit runner
packages; but is no longer necessary.

Resolves #896.
title: Remove aspnetvnext and dotnet-cli feeds
